alert.note: Alert for Cabarrus (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 28 at 7:55AM EST until January 29 at 1:28AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM EST THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Rowan County, North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 100 PM EST. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding expected in low-lying and poor drainage areas. River or stream flows remain elevated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 746 AM EST, Gauge reports indicate a few streams in the area have risen out of their banks. In particular, North Second Creek near US 70 is above bankfull stage in the Woodleaf area, flooding adjacent farmland and other low-lying areas with up to 2 feet of inundation. Stream crossings could be underwater at White Rd, Lyerly Rd, Upright Rd, Graham Rd, Hall Rd, Childers Rd, and Bear Poplar Rd. Also, Grants Creek at Rowan Mill Rd near Salisbury has risen out of its banks and could cause similar impacts on roads in that area. Small streams elsewhere in western and central Rowan County could continue to rise for a time today before receding, and some additional low-water crossings could be impacted. - Flooding impacts will continue much of today, but no additional rainfall is expected. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Kannapolis, Salisbury, China Grove, Spencer, Landis, Enochville, Cleveland, Piedmont Research Station, Woodleaf and Mount Ulla. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Turn around, don`t drown! When it is safe to do so, please report flooding threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed.
